etymology.description: ideogrammic: 匕 + 巛 (“hair”) + 囟 (“head; fontanel”); later 匕 → 肉 (“flesh”).
etymology.interpretation: Early forms combined the top of the skull/fontanel with flowing hair to depict the head, and were later marked with the flesh component to signal a body organ. Together they point to the fleshy organ within the head, hence the sense of brain and by extension mind.
etymology.simplification: Graphic simplification from 腦 to 脑 by replacing the complex right-side 𡿺 with 㐫 while retaining the left-side 肉 as 月, reducing strokes but keeping the semantic cue of ‘flesh’.

examples.chinese: 我今天脑子有点儿乱(我今天腦子有點兒亂)。
examples.english: My mind is a bit messy today.

examples.chinese: 医生检查了他的脑部(醫生檢查了他的腦部)。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng jiǎnchá le tā de nǎobù.

examples.chinese: 这个问题得动动脑筋(這個問題得動動腦筋)。
